It was a real winner.. for the guy who will only eat pizzas as well as for the more adventurous eaters in our group. The mezze was superb, the chicken baharat excellent, the lentil soup and poached eggs with garlic yogurt and greens made me feel I was visiting Istanbul again.
The friendly, attentive service added to the experience topped by the moderate prices for what was really quality food.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: This place serves Mediterranean food with a Turkish accent and does a great job of it. We started out with three of their appetizer spreads with delicious warm bread and it was just wonderful. I had striped bass and the others had beef cheeks and lamb stew served in a clay pot. The three of us went through two bottles of excellent red wine - ask the owner to recommendations; he knows what he's doing. The waiter was a lot of fun and the place was buzzing with all sorts of people. Best meal in NYC on this visit.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Love this place. Been going for a number of years, and it's my home away from home, as well as the place I always take out of town friends.  The owner (Hussein) is almost always there and is a jewel. The staff is friendly, the vibe relaxed, the food great.  Lebne is the best I've had; turkish patican (eggplant/tomatoes), delish.  Best lentil soup ever. Everything I've eaten is good--from the superb brick oven pizza to beyti kabab (lamb), stuffed cabbage (stuffed with lamb and rice--not your Jewish mama's kind, but just as good!).  The food is so well prepared, as well as tasty. Good place to go as a couple, with family, with friends, or even by yourself (a single woman is treated just as well).

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
I can't remember ever eating at a Turkish/Mediterranean restaurant before.  I'm glad that we tried Bodrum - it was a nice change of pace.

To start, service was friendly.  We enjoyed the bread, especially when eaten with the appetizers.

Appetizers were very nicely flavored.  The braised leeks were not what I expected but still tasted good.

For entrees, the kids had pizzas which were a decent size.  The adults both had lamb dishes which were cooked to perfection.  They were incredibly tender.  Also, the Turkish rice was something that I've never had before - I'm not sure how it is prepared but it was a wonderful accompaniment.

The prices were very fair and a good value.

I would definitely recommend trying this place at least once.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Love this local Mediterranean spot. Food is consistently good--bread and olives, mezze or Shepard salad and consistently good little lamb chops at a great price. Other meat or fish main courses may be the weakest. But the pizza's from the brick oven are first rate. Go on Monday for 1/2 price bottles of very drinkable wine.
reviewTitle: Upper West Side fare and a fair price

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Our group of four enjoyed dining here. It was just what we needed after a day of travel to NYC but we probably wont be going back. Even before the entrees arrived we stuffed ourselves with the bread with olive oil (and olives) which the attentive staff continuously replenished. The oven is one thing that this restaurant has going for it! The food is pretty bland though. The chicken sis kebab was OK, but I have had more flavorful versions of this dish in many other restaurants. The dish was supposed to include basmati rice but the rice that actually came with it was probably Uncle Ben's or some other type of quick cook plastic. The vegetarian pizza wasn't very exciting either.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: The Turkish Sis Kebab and the Chicken Sis Kebab were tender and had a great charred flavor.  The best way to judge is often the veggies, and these were outstanding.  Try the Turkish coffee it is quite an experience.  Mondays are ½ price wine days, which adds value to an already good choice.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
The staff could have been a little more attentive but they weren't terrible. 

First of all the fresh sesame bread here was very good. We asked for seconds. Love the olive oil with olives they provided instead of butter. Here is what we ate:

Artichoke pizza- the pizza was excellant. Very thin and crispy, dough was great, fresh tomato sauce. THe artichokes were marinated and not fresh. 

Crispy calimari - uninteresting. Nothing special about this. 

Moussaka - a little mushy and not that flavorful

Turkish sis kabab- the lamb was cooked perfectly and loved the veggies that came with which were seasoned nicely.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: With glasses of Turkish wine, we began with the appetizer sampler (six or so of the menu choices) paired with fresh baked bread.  Choosing then two of the favorite appetizers and a lamb and a chicken entree, we were delighted with the quality and quantity.  No need for dessert and a desire to return for another meal sometime soon.  Service attentive.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We were the family and some friends for dinner.
The food was fantastic - everything we ordered was perfect.
The Musaka and Lamb Tandir were GREAT!!!
I highly recommend this restaurant for everyone.
The owner is very nice as well.
reviewTitle: Excellent Food for an affordable price

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Our appetizers came aftet the entrees except for my wife who didn't get her kebabs for another 15 minutes. The food was so-so with only some of the food of Turkish origin. Super noisy means no quiet conversations.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Delicious food at an affordable price. I will definitely go back. Don't pass up the fresh warm bread - really fantastic. Service was also very good.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: After standing for 10 minutes and being ignored we finally grabbed a waiter who led us inside the restaurant to wait for another person, who was on the phone. Finally we were given a table but told we must be out within 90 minutes. We then sat and waited to be served. My partner ordered a bottle of wine and I was then asked what I wanted to drink! We noted the wait staff congregated in a corner of the restaurant up to six at time chatting. We then had to signal to ask for bread and after some flurry of action, the bread arrived before the bread plate. When the meal arrived it was good. So the chef can be complimented! However, the waiters who earlier were nowhere to be seen, now descended upon us to whip the plates away before the meal was finished. After, yet another lull in the service, we again signalled across the floor to request the dessert menu. We then waited to give our order... Only to again be offered the dessert menu. The dessert arrived without cutlery. At last the meal was complete... The plates removed... And this was when spoons were put on our table. They helpfully provided three options for the gratuity, which I guess helps the less numerate tipper! And demonstrates their misplaced optimism.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We stumbled across this restaurant whilst wandering in the neighbourhood one night (our hotel was near). It was cold outside and this place looked really cosy. There was a short queue for a table once we got inside but we didn't wait longer than a few minutes to be seated. There is an open wood pizza oven and the heat from that was very welcome. 
It's a small, cosy venue with a lot of tables in a small space but we didn't feel too overwhelmed by this. I'm not sure I would think the same if I was going for a romantic meal though.
The staff were attentive and helpful when asked about the menu. We had a sharing mezze platter to start and our waiter was really good explaining what everything was and what it was made of...and we didn't even ask him! Lovely bread handed out freely too.
The portion sizes were just right for us...not too big but we were fully satisfied.
We had three courses each with a couple of glasses of wine and it came to about $90 (£60)
which we thought was pretty reasonable.
Overall, if were back in the neighbourhood again, we would definitely return.
reviewTitle: Good food and a nice cosy atmosphere

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: A cozy, but a bit noisy place, the starters were good, although they forgot our bread, we had to ask for it, even though our neighbor-table was offered bread three times! And before we had finished our starters, we could see our main courses waiting for us on a table in the restaurant. If it was the kitchen or waiters that was planning it wrong we don't know, but it meant that when we recieved our main coruse (pizza and kofte) it was almost cold! The manager was a bit invasive, asking us about why we didn't tip when we had not even finished our wine. The service in general was not that good and the food quality was lower than average of what I would expect in a European country. For 2 starter, pizza and kofte and the cheapest bottle of wine, the bill was at 83 USD, quite expensive for an average experience. I will probably not come again.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Good Turkish/ Mediterranean cuisine in a relaxed setting. Wood oven and great bread is a definite plus. One of our 'go-to' places for lunch.
reviewTitle: Good food in a relaxed neighborhood venue

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We were starving for food and nothing could have made our day but food. We ordered for Samosas. The samosas were yummmm with 3 amazing chutneys. Though the portion size of Samosa is too small and just 2 samosas per plate, but it was delicious. We ordered for methi malai mutter and Malai marke paneer with Butter rotis. The rotis were very soft. The paneer sabji was really yummm.. The daal was without tadka but good. Was surprised to see Paneer in Methi sabzi and it was okay. I would say the portion size is too less here. There is no jeera rice here and the plain rice comes with peas rice but it seemed as if some rice fell on the way. The bowl was not even half fill. Besides the portion the food is yumm followed by good mukhwaas. Worth visiting.
reviewTitle: Best Indian food had here in US

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This is 4 and 5th time to this wonderful restaurant.  I recommend this place and the food that I had with friends two days in a row.  Purani Delhi Ki Papri Chat, lamb chops, chicken kali mirch (beware it is hot) and goat curry.  Delightfully prepared and very delicious.  Please go and try it out - and it is not expensive by NY standards.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I took my son to Museum of Mathematics and on the way we ran into "Dhaba". He asked to go there, so we booked a table near the window for 4pm to avoid lunch craziness and insanety of dinner time. We both ordered "favorites/famous" dishes. Both were just ok. I ate less than half. My son did not like his choice at all. We`ve eaten in at least 2 dozen indian restaraunts, and this one, in our opinion, not higher than a middle, not the worst one, but way far off from the best either.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
This is my wife's and my favorite North Indian cuisine on Lexington Ave, NY.  Wide variety of choices in the menu that includes several vegetarian options. 

Very few restaurants maintain consistent taste and this is one of them.  METHI MATTAR MALAI PANEER, PANEER KALI MIRCH and LANGARWALI DAAL are our favorite veg dishes.  This restaurant is a paradise for non-veg lovers and KALMI KABAB and PAHADI MURGH TIKKA are few of my favorites.  

Very busy restaurant tightly packed during weekends and I recommend reserving a table 2 hrs ahead.  Visited several times with Friends and Family and always leave the restaurant happy.  

Give it a shot and am sure this place will become one of your favorites as well.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: we have been to this NYC restaurant twice and enjoyed memorable meals here.  Each dinner choice was so tasty. We had a cauliflower appetizer, samosas, potatoes w green peas, chicken tandoori, madras curry and veg paneer basmati rice dish. Exquisite flavors. Every table was being served and it's obvious why. Make this your NYC Indian selection.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The reviews for this place were good. So I followed the reviews. The place is a bit crowded. Went for the weekend buffet. It was for $13. I was not impressed. I like my Indian food spicy. This was a bit toned down. There was some variety though I have seen more.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Good good, not too spicy.  A bit overpriced.  Great hangout for a friends night out. The mango lassi was great.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I thought the food was above average in quality and quantity, but it's certainly overpriced.  Service was poor.. we got there while they were still open and a lot of the dinner options were not available ("the staff has gone").  I think our server may have been tipsy, but not sure.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Very good food, made right, not too spicy. I never heard of this place before till now, when my friends told me about this place. From jersey it is a little bit far but it seems like it worth the trip to NY.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
This restaurant is a bit crowded and not very spacious. But they make up for all this by the excellent food they serve. Good cleanliness.They have a wholesome Buffet with a good variety of Indian cuisine, the lamb biriyani was delicious, an excellent chaat counter, good and pleasant waiters!!

Their prices are reasonable and they serve good tasty authentic Indian food!! Would recommend this place.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We really liked the food and the service too. Food was excellent specially Panner Kali Mirch and Lassi.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Nice to have a decent Indian curry but the place is very crowded and the food comes fast so not a real dining experience. If you want a enjoy the nice Indian flavors it worth a visit. Reasonable prices and good taste.
reviewTitle: nice indian food but very crowded

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
We went for buffet lunch. This restaurant is too congested  and limited options in buffet.

1. Butter-naan was not properly cooked.
2. Only one dessert and that too was very bad.

I was extremely disappointed and  would not recommend anyone to go to this place.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Over the years, we have dined at Dhaba too many times to count. Dhaba appears to have changed ownership. It has joined those so called “HIP” Restaurants where music with a high bass is played. That makes everyone talk louder to those at their table, ETC. The high level of others talking loudly to overcome the music has transform Dhaba into something unpleasant. We will not return.

We dined here on May 20, 2014 with a party of four adults. The quality of the Chicken Tika Msla, Shrimp Curry, Basmati Rice, Garlic Naan was still very good. But due to the high noise level, we must cross Dhaba off our list.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Lots of delicious Indian food for a reasonable price.  Great variety.  Every item is tasty, fragrant, and served at the proper temperature.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Went to this place a week ago for lunch as it was rated one of the best restaurant for Indian food but the food here surprised me. The expectations with which I went was far way ahead then what I went with.
Amazing, delicious, etc. will visit again n again

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: My husbands favorite is Indian. This was a good choice for the family, although typically I have a problem with overly spicy food. We had chicken and lamb birany and it was good. Considering the crowd, service was slow, but ok.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Absolutely terrific food, perfectly flavored, cooked and presented. Excellent, professional service, with minimal delays despite the crowd.  And it was very, very crowded on this Saturday night in early March!  So crowded and tightly packed that exiting from our seats at a large center table was nearly impossible without bumping into wait staff, and tables and customers sitting behind or adjacent to us. The noise level also made conversation difficult; so I'd go elsewhere if you are looking for a more intimate experience. While all dishes were excellent, we agreed that stand outs were: the cauliflower appetizer, lasoni gobi; the eggplant masala; the lamb and chicken kormas; and a lentil dish, langarwali daal.  On the weekend, reservations are a must; and even then you may experience a short wait.  Our large party of 6 was seated about 20-25 minutes after our reservation time.  Would go back in a heart beat, but next time might try for a weeknight or earlier or later in the evening.
reviewTitle: Best Indian food I have had in NYC

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We tasted a number of veg and non-veg dishes and all were not too spicy and amazing.service was prompt.the dimly lit restaurant creates an inviting ambience.however one does experience difficulty when trying to read the menu.all meat is halal.i will visit again.
reviewTitle: Indian food that makes you want to eat more!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I pretty much only eat one dish at Indian restaurants so I've had it many times and this one by far was the most flavorful.  It was slightly different then most places make, but that's a good thing.  Although a tad too spicy for my liking, next time I'd tell them to make it just slightly less spicy.  My only complaint is that the toilet is that which you'd find in a dive bar.  Wobbly sink, banged up door, no decorations.  So much detail seemed to go into the restaurant's atmosphere and then when I walk into the bathroom it's like being back at my college bar, not pleasant.  They should invest a bit in this.  Regardless, I'd go back for the food.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: We've been to this little Mediterranean place several times in Feb & Mar of 2013. Freshly-made hummus served with a warm bread is a great starter. The medium sized wood burning stove pizza is delicious....a thin crust with top-of-the-line ingredients from Italy and surrounding countries. The chicken or salmon is a great choice for lunch--cooked with precision so it is moist & flavorful. The salads are generous sized..try the greek with feta. We love the wide range of moderately priced wines. Enjoy 1/2 price bottles on wine Mondays.
reviewTitle: Great food & service in a lovely, small space

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We came to Bodrum for a celebration dinner for my husband, along with our daughter and son-in-law.  We started with the sampling plate, and a melted cheese plate, which were brought with spears of crusty bread. The sampler was mostly things that you dip into, so another time I would ask also for flat bread, and for my own needs if there was a gluten-free alternative dipper.  

For entrees, we ordered Lamb tagine, braised lamb shank, and wood-oven roasted half chicken.  All were delicious.  The chicken was the larger plate, ideal for my tall SIL.  I had about a third of my tagine cartoned, as I was satisfied and full, and it was good cold on the airplane the next day. 

The service was perfect, attentive but unobtrusive.  I established that the young man hanging out near our table was there waiting for our order.  He was not chatting or being obnoxious, I just had to ask him if he was our waiter.  He was very sweet.  

We are accustomed, in our trips to New York, for many of the restaurants to have small tables closely packed.  This was the case here, though not nearly as tightly packed as some places.  We had ample space to eat and talk, but I tucked the carton on my lap when our dessert came. We shared a molten chocolate cake, and something else, perhaps cheesecake.  They simply put a birthday candle in the chocolate cake for hubby's birthday, which was as he likes to celebrate in a restaurant, not too much fuss.  

We were happily surprised with the prices, not one of our entrees was over $20.  We are used to paying more for a sit-down restaurant in NYC.  We would definitely come here again.  There were some people at another table, who told us they needed to come here to be comforted following Hurricane Sandy, though getting there was more challenge than usual for them as the subway was out.  As the food was delicious, I can see why they would choose this restaurant for rest and comfort.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Bodrum is a great little restaurant.  Many interesting menu choices.  The appetizers and main courses that my wife and I enjoyed at our recent visit were great.  This restaurant is not very expensive and provides very good value.  Also, I must eat gluten free and they have many selections that met my needs.  The only negative is that this restaurant is small and the tables are very close together, so you do have to contend with other people's conversations.  Not a place a romantic dinner, but a definitely a very good choice for a good meal and interesting food.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
This is a small cozy place on the upper west side. The food is excellent! I love a place that can elavate simple foods to artistic heights and this place does just that. The breads are perfect and the various spreads are indiviually crafted and seasoned. This is not a place where the hommus and everything else all tastes the same (one of my pet peeves in middle eastern places). This is turkish food done right. All the smoky and peppery flavors are here, fresh, bright and bold. 

The lamb dumplings in a sour yought sauce - yummy. Service was friendlt and refined. 

Nice place. The interior space is small so make reservations if you have a group of more then four people. The out door space is noce, a little cramped.

They have a large brick oven in the front room so I imagine the pizza as perfect as well but we didn't try them. 

We will be back!

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: I went with my wife and two friends -- they had been several times, for us it was a first. The first courses (the four of us shared five) were more than satisfactory; the entrees (we had branzino in a bed of fennel) were excellent; the dessert (rice pudding) was very tasty. No complaints about the service. However, unless one had mastered sign language and/or lip reading it was virtually impossible to hear anyone else at the table -- and we had been placed in what we were told was the quietest corner of the restaurant!
reviewTitle: Excellent food, fine service but obnoxiously noisy!

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: I walked here in the sweltering New York heat excited to discover a new restaurant and when I arrived I remembered I had been to a family dinner a few years ago.Nice ambience and a neighborhood restaurant feel, relaxed, friendly and cozy but not too small, I ordered babganoosh and ate the whole order by myself since my tablemate doesn't lke eggplant. It was perfectly done, just the right consistency and a little smoky. Even the bread was good! Ordered lamb shank with couscous because I was just too hot and tired to cut meat. The lamb fell off the bone and the pearl couscous was very good. You could have a whole meal of appetizers instead if you want more of a taste of everything. The staff was very attentive. There are many different lamb dishes to choose from, fish etc, as well as many appetizers. The salads are fresh and light. In a neighborhood where there are many small restaurants, this is a winner.It is expensive for the neighborhood but fairly priced for New York, We had two appetizers and two entrees plus cold drinks for about  $75.00 but I think my entree was the most expensive on the menu.I would have been upset if the food and service were lacking; however this restaurant is consistently good so I left happy.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Eclectic menu with excellent moussaka, a dish I had given up on years ago because it was so mediocre at restaurants we have visited. At Bodrum it was a down to earth feast.bThe lamb dishes are terrific, pizza delicious. A great discovery.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: I live in the neighborhood and this has become my restaurant of choice (maybe I'm unwise to be telling you all about it lest it be overrun by customers, but you all have shared a lot of good tips so I want to reciprocate!)  The pizzas are delicious, the kebabs are excellent and the Turkish flat bread is not only the best flat bread, but probably the best bread period that I have ever eaten in a restaurant.  Great babaganoush too.  The Shiraz I had was also very very good.  Go early to get a seat outside as it fills up fast on the weekends.  I was surprised to see that other reviewers felt this place is pricey - I actually think for the quality it compares very well to other NYC restaurants, not sure what that's all about.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: This would be a definitely thumbs-up if a little less pricey. As it is, it would be more appropriate as a "fancy" place, which it is not. Anyway, food here is nice, I went there with two friend and we all ordered differente dishes - all were good and plentiful. The small sampler appetizer plate did not taste as good as I had in Turkey (should it?), but was fair enough. All in all, I would recommend it to anyone living nearby and looking for a convenient option.
reviewTitle: Nice turkish food, a bit pricey

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Nice service, good selection of Mediterranean items and good Turkish wine. Kind of pricey, but, an interesting change from the usual Italian fare. Upper West Side is is great family location!

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We managed to get a table here on the night before Thankgiving holiday but we were lucky as the restaurant was absolutely packed to the gunnels - we only came across the place by chance so hadn't made advance reservations.
We didn't have an appetiser and both chose the Beyti Kebab which was not a huge portion but was really very good. I have to say that although we didn't try them that the pizzas also looked very good and the brick oven gave the place a warm atmosphere on a chilly evening.
The service was very attentive and the Turkish flat bread was yummy!
There was a pretty good wine list and a tried a nice white rioja which was just the job.
To finish off I tried the baklava which was good and husband had ice cream - he said that he thought the vanilla ice cream was over sweet - but that it being really picky!
Would certainly come back here again on our next visit to New York so that says it all.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We went to Bodrum 2 weeks ago for brunch and it was a real let down. My girl got the Turkish scrambled eggs with feta, dill, tomatoes, scallions, and grilled pita, and I got the Yesil Salad which has lettuce, black olives, dill, scallions, cucumbers and feta with a lemon vinaigrette.

The most disappointing part was the eggs. About 3 bites in my girl got a crunch; yep...a big piece of egg shell. She searched around a bit and found a few more pieces as well. Rather revolting. Additionally, based on the menu description, we thought the vegetables would be mixed into the eggs, but it was all placed on top like a small salad. The raw scallions and were a bit overpowering in my opinion and would have probably benefited from being cooked a bit with the egg mixture. Just a personal preference I suppose.

As for my salad, it was a real yawner. The lettuce was limp and old, the vinagrette was weak and they put just a few crumbs of feta on top. It just wasn't interesting to eat.

Bodrum has that awesome brick oven inside, so their baked stuff is usually great. But in the few times we've gone, everything else has been really hit and miss, including the service. Can't recommend them for anything aside from the baked goods really.
reviewTitle: Hit or miss quality makes this place rather average

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
My fiance and I were feeling like Turkish after a Yankees game and we randomly picked this restaurant off OpenTable.

It is located on the Upper West Side on Amsterdam. It has outdoor seating (too hot when we went) and a cozy interior which was clean and bright.

Food was good. My fiance had the adana lamb kebab and I the adana chicken. They had tomoato sauce on both kebabs which we didn't get in Turkey but I liked it. They also serve freshly baked Turkish bread which was delicious. Finally, they had Efes Beer which we had when over in Turkey and loved. Besides Zaytinya in Washington DC, this is first time we saw it in the US so we were happy.

My fiance and I will certainly dine here again.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
We didn't research this place before, we were just wandering around for a place to eat and it looked good - especailly the "Half price wine bottle on monday with a purchase of an entree"

It seems there is more than one location, we went to the one close to central park.
W had a bottle of wine, moussaka, pizza and dessert to go(since we were kind of full) - all told $57 before tip.

I really liked the moussaka, a different style of presentation - lots of eggplant, no potatoes - i think its the best moussaka i've had, but perhaps people that know turkish food would have different opinions.  My husband liked his pizza.  I do remember that the bread was really tasty.  Apparently they get it from some turkish bakery every day, i think we have two lots of it.  The baklava was ok, it wasn't anything special, but it was moist rather than dry so i was happy with that.

i would go back to this place if we were ever in the area again.
reviewTitle: Veyr tasty - go on monday, cheap wine

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Mixed appy platter - best deal in town and absolutely delicious.  Another appetizer-eggplant with carmelized onions, ate every crumb.  Lamb shank dinner, beautifully seasoned.  Waitstaff is super attentive.  I would go back and just order lots of appetizers.  Didn't have pizza but it look wonderful.   Really nice neighborhood restaurant with gentle prices.

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: Wonderful lamb tagine, grilled clams, prosciutto and arugula brick-oven pizza and the best rice-pudding this side of town!
reviewTitle: Wonderful lamb tagine, grilled clams, prosciutto and arugula brick-oven pizza and the best rice-pudding this side of...

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText: yummmm

placeAddress: 584 Amsterdam Ave between 88th & 89th St, New York City, NY 10024
reviewText:
My wife and I discovered Bodrum, a charming small Turkish Mediterranean Restaurant with both indoor and outdoor tables, in a relaxed setting on Amsterdam Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan between 88th and 89th Streets. Bodrum Restaurant opened in June 2007 after renovations at the sites of a former poodle grooming salon, a dry cleaner and a Russian chicken restaurant. As most Manhattanites were away for summer holiday, Bodrum is just being discovered. By the way, 'Bodrum'  is the name is a Turkish town popular with summer tourists.

We shared a fine mushroom soup bordering on a creme soup, very very fine. We shared a 'Mezze', which is a sampling of mediterranean specialties, including hummus, babaghanoush, Turkish eggplant, Moroccan spicy chicken, Turkish fillo stuffed with French Feta, and yougurt cheese mixed with walnuts.

Our waiter was quiet friendly, and quite Turkish. The service, water glasses, bread, blue cloth napkins, and metal silverware spoke of a caliber of restaurant far beyond what would expect to find in the 'moderate' price range.

The restaurant offers Turkish and Swordfish kebab and a variety of fish served both American and Moroccan style, as well as a selection of regular or whole wheat pizza pies from a wood-burning oven, a full bar, a desert menu, and local delivery. All in all, quiet a pleasant surprise and a charming new place to try. Bodrum appears to be a low key place for couples looking for a private experience. Seating is limited-not a place for large groups. The restaurant has a website while has their menu, but the website is apparently still under construction and has not posted any photos yet.

Rating

Food 95
Decor 95
Prices-Moderate
Seating-Limited
Service 100
Atmosphere 100
Website-Has menu posted, still under construction
reviewTitle: A Charming New Turkish Mediterranean Restaurant

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Wonderful Indian cuisine. We enjoyed the Sunday buffet. A variety of options and all were delicious. My only complaint s that it is very small and the tables are very close to one another. But can't beat the food.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: When in the mood for some nice spicy food and authentic Indian flavours Dhaba will do the trick. Being Indian myself i can say that this place is above average. Nice atmosphere and clean restaurant as well. Reservation required as it can be packed at times.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This was the best Indian food I've ever had and the service was excellent.  The restaurant is small so reservations are needed.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Abbiamo scelto questo ristorante con alcuni colleghi dopo aver sentito qualche amico che vive a Ny.
Il locale molto affollato ma il servizio è veloce e la qualità buona. Consiglio la prenotazione.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Glad we had reserved a table as the queue was all the way out the door on Friday night. Small cost noisy place, quite dark and very lively. The food was truly delicious. Very authentic flavours and also a "British curry" section which was a real treat for expats in the US!
reviewTitle: Delicious. Worth booking at the weekend!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
we were told that the chef grinds the spices daily and BOY HOWDY! does it show! We had chicken, lamb and the paneer and all were excellent with exciting spicy flavors! 

Could this be my new favorite Manhattan Indian joint?  I THINK SO!!!!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We were referred to Dhaba by a work colleague, tried it, loved it.  We are definitely going back.  The food was very good, freshly prepared, hot, spicy, delicious, and the price was right.
reviewTitle: Our new favorite spot for Indian

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
I have to admit I have never been to the actual restaurant; I only use their delivery service.
However, I have been a customer for about a year now and perhaps can offer some insight into their curry.
Firstly, this is not Indian food as you would experience it on the subcontinent. This is more like the English curry place down the street. It has its advantages and disadvantages. The advantage is that you have a consistency in the quality. The sauces are premade and retain their flavor. However, very few if any changes can be made (vindaloo comes as vinegary as the sauce was made originally); perhaps they can add more heat, however, they cannot take the heat out.
As a decent curry takes time to make, this is a better bet for a high turnover, take away style place than making slow cooked curry to order. 
Unfortunately the naan arrives quite soggy so I do not recommend ordering it for take-out.
All in all, if you are an ex-pat and miss your pub's curry, come to Dhaba (order from the English menu, much better than the mish mash on the rest of it). if you want to eat authentic Indian food, you are likely to disappoined. However, sadly, you are likely to be disappointed anywhere else on Curry Hill, too.
A few notes on delivery: they are popular. If you are unlucky, you may have to wait. However, most of the time food comes on time. Make sure they read back your order; the background noise does lead to misunderstandings easily.
reviewTitle: Reminds me of the curry places in England

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Our family ate here on the Wednesday night before Thanksgiving. It was a good sign that every table was full when we arrived. Even so we were seated within 20 minutes. All the dishes were very good. We ordered 3 different chicken dishes, 1 lamb dish, plus rice and bread for the table. The stout I was drinking was a perfect accompaniment to the lamb. The noise level was energetic, but not too loud to be able to hear the others in your party. We definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone looking for Indian cuisine in the area.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I don't remember another time I've been so full! And that's a good thing. I seriously loved this restaurant. We went there and ordered a variety of things just to try the flavors. It hit the spot (multiple times over!) It is a little dim in the restaurant, but that really adds to the ambiance and spirit of the place. The service is above par, and the food is worth every penny. I highly recommend a visit to this restaurant - just make sure you have time to walk it off afterwards :)

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
The restaurant is good. I visited in 2012. 

I was impressed with the food. NOthing great with Taste but then I remembered I was out of India and given the choice, I think it was a good one. I wish the restaurant was brightly lit. The reason I remember this restaurant was that I was one of the last diners late in the evening and the guys helped me out with a taxi. 

The hotel could have been brightly lit. Its a bit dark. But its good.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Food is excellent - staff is great and prices are very reasonable. Went with a customer who travels to India often and a business partner who is from Pakistan - both rated the food excellent.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Nothing special, the food is decent but none of the dishes stood out for me. The service was slow for a weekday.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
I ate at Dhaba's with 3 friends.
Our food was excellent, but plates were large and we should probably only have ordered 3 dishes instead of 4.

The restaurant had a stylish decor, but was a bit noisy.
Still, I think it's the best Indian restaurant in the neighborhood, and I would definitly eat there again.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
I have been to a lot of Indian places in NYC and this place has got it right! Their kali mirch chicken (and paneer) is something I order every time and is always amazing. 

The seating area could be a little tight on busy nights but the food would not disappoint you. Try it!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
This is a great place to come and eat.  You can usually tell if the place is good by the number of empty seats (or lack thereof) and the queue out the door.  On both visits in the last week there were no seats and a line out the door.  

The only negative I can give this place is that the noise levels can very quickly get to insane levels.  The low ceiling and narrow space amplifies this.

However, despite that it is a *MUST* visit location for sure.  The food is superb and fresh tasting.  I had the Kashmiri Rogan Josh (Lamb), this was spicier than I've had it before, but it really was good.  The increase spice was easily fixed with some wine.  The nan bread was great and the Papadums that are delivered when you sit down are one of the better ones I've had.  No idea what made them so much better but they certainly were.  You'll get a free refill of them too, so win win :D

As it's not far from the usual hotel, it might make the regular list of places to eat at when I'm in the city.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Our party of five lucked into a table at the front of the restaurant up a step and by the window, which set us apart from the busy main dining room but not so far that we would be forgotten by the waiter. Start with a ginger lime fizz and some samosas. Skip the bland paneer pakora. Move on to excellent tawa gobi aloo and chicken korma (get the dark meat) or better yet lamb rogan josh. Don't forget the 5-lentil Dal and some Poori. My only complaint is beyond minor: I despise drinking from those mason jar water glasses. Can't wait for the death of that awful trend.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: After you get over the initial feeling of being completely disorientated (as the noise really hits you as you walk through the door)... You soon settle in to your comfortable seat, and are treated to great service and one of the best indian meals you'll ever have. Seriously. Perfect portion sizes, great quality food and the favours.... Wow! Your taste buds are in for a real treat.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The best Indian Restaurant I have ever been to outside India. A bit overcrowded. The service is pretty good.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
The combination of "British" Indian curries and draft German beer. Wow - I thought I'd died and gone to heaven! Indeed the Vindaloo was excellent, as was the Korma my wife had. Naans also really up there with anything you would find in England, and that is a huge compliment.

As to the restaurant itself - it was heavingly busy and we showed up literally 1 minute late and they were already calling us to see if they could give away our table - so be on time! Of course, that made it pretty noisy too - too noisy really - but at least it ended up slowing the service down a little from the usual US-focus of rushing everything.

The funniest thing was how dimly lit it was. I swear the lightbulbs must have been about 4 Watts and we had to use our cellphones as flashlights to read the menu. Seriously.

We will return! We will be on time, And we WILL bring a flashlight.

If you find this review helpful, I'd appreciate your vote.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We got in just in time. The food was good, although the extra spicy curry was just to hot to actually taste anything. The service was good but got a little slow once every spot in the restaurant was filled. Overall a good place with tasty food.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
We only wish that Dhaba was located in Arizona! So far, this is the best that we found in AZ, NC, UT and NYC. 

Our family party of four dined here again on April 25, 2013. For starters we ordered drinks and then our meal. Two orders of Chicken Tika Marsala @ $16 each, 1 chicken white meat @ $15, one Saag Paneer @ $14, two wonderfully cooked garlic naan @ $3.50 each, 2 basmati rice and one mango chutney @ $3. Our totoal cost was $108 + tip. Not expensive for a great meal!

The service was great as we never had to hunt down a server. The food is excellent as we will return on our next NYC visit!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Wehad Sunday buffet lunch. $13 each. Very tasty North Indian food with pain puri, pav bhaji and bhel which are Mumbai street foods as appetizers. The chicken tikka masala was good as was the chicken chilli. 3 veg dishes were all tasty but there was no dal on the table. The ambience is good and the pulsating Punjabi music adds to the atmosphere. Seating is very tight so you have to weave your way through a lot of seated patrons for the buffet. Clean enough restrooms. Only complaint was it took a full 5 minutes after we came back from the buffet with loaded plates before the freshly made bread basket showed up at the table. The chicken tandoori appetizer which was delicious came even a couple minutes later. Overall though you can't go wrong with Dhaba here in the Murray Hill area also known as Litlle India.
reviewTitle: Excellent authentic Indian food - try the lunch buffet for value

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Enjoyed the food very much and would go there again. Not so much for the ambiance though as it was very loud and seating was very tight. Service was very good and their recommendations were appreciated.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I Just Planned to visit Indian restaurant in Lexington Ave.. upon the reviews on Dhaba i decided to hav lunch over there.. Lunch Buffet was awesome.... Chicken Tikka Masala tasted good ..the creamy sauce used was nice.. Naan was best i ever had ..n the Shrimp Curry is a spicy Home style dish.. Service was good and attentive... This was sure a hang out place... i will plan to visit this restaurant again with my friends

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
The restaurant was packed, and ergo, kinda loud. Hard to carry on a conversation at times. Also, in late January, every time the door was opened, it was freezing.

On the other hand, it's the best Indian food I've had in a long time, perhaps ever. Go in spring, and either early or late, and you'll be fine.
reviewTitle: Great food, but loud and cold

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The food nice and they have a long confusing menu, but over its nice. But i dont know why the long line...it wasnt worth the wait
reviewTitle: wonder whats the crowd here for

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Nice place, good food. Good tunes playing, and not too loud like some reviews said. We were early evening, 6pm, and was busy. The kids were made welcome. Not bad price for NYC.
reviewTitle: Cool atmosphere, good food. Nearly as good as a UK curry, and that's saying something!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
We stayed in new York for five days 
Found this restaurant on first night it was busy which is a. Good sign
We met a waiter called leon (Leonard)
He made us feel very welcome
My husband is a vegan although Indian restaurants do vegetarian my husband is quite difficult to cater for he likes his food very spivey but not dry
He enjoyed his meal very much
My meal was Excellant
We sdid we would go back the next day in fact we went for the five days
Each day my husbands meal was better and better that was due to Leonard's expertise and advise of what he thought John would like
They gave us complimentary drinks which was a fantastic gesture for returning day after day
Like to thank all staff and the chef 
A special thanks to Leonard for excellent service
Hope we will return to new York just to have fantastic Indian food
Val and John portugal

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: My husband and I enjoyed this one of many fine Indian restaurants in the Flatiron/Gramercy Park neighborhoods. It was some of the best naan and Saag Paneer I've ever had. Take your friends!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
During our recent trip to NYC, we dined at Dhaba again on November 19, 2012. While traveling from the EWR Airport in the late afternoon, I called for a 8PM reservation. We arrived at Dhaba on time and there was a short wait for our table–no real issue.

Our party of five ordered: 3 Kingfish beers, 4 Garlic Naan, 4 Diet Cokes, 1 Purani Papdi Chaat, 1 Aldo Tikki Chaat, 1 Sham Savera, 2 Chicken Tika Msla, 1 Chicken chite meat, 1 Tandoori Mix Grill, 2 Basmati Rice.Everything arrived as ordered and was very good and equal to our past visits here.Total cost was $149 + tip–very reasonable for the quality and service.

We look forward to our next visit here as we highly recommend Dhaba!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Went here with my wife during a brief visit to NYC for a concert at Madison Square Garden.we arrivedin the restaurant to be presented with a buffet lunch menu at the cost of $10.95.The food on offer was classic Indian cuisine, of a high standard, the service was lightning quick, and it was very busy.Would return here tomorrow, no complaints from either of us.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The food was very interesting and tasty.  Most things were not that spicy and the naan was wonderfully fluffy.  The decor is not very Indian like.  It's a bit clubby which is ok but the music was a little much.  Pretty good though.  The lemon soda was good.
reviewTitle: Tasty curry - great naan - a bit too much club atmosphere perhaps

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This is a nice restaurant with good srrvice and food. The problem is that it is dqrk, and very noisy. Dont plan on a romantic dinner or one thwt you can easily converse in. The food is good but spicy.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Although we had a couple of recommendations for good Indian restaurants in this area, the Dhaba was the busiest by far. The food was excellently spiced and delicious. Service  was speedy, attentive and efficient. The meal was excellent value for money, delivered in a stylish and atmospheric setting. We would definitely return.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The food was of high quality and was fresh.  The main dishes were spicy, so you may want to ask that the heat level be toned down.  Be aware that the place is busy and noisy; the atmosphere is festive, but it's difficult to hold a conversation.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I'm an Indian food connoisseur, so yes, I am a bit picky with the Indian joints I go to. Dhaba in New York City is one of the better ones. A little more chic than many other Indian restaurants, it's got an indie feel to it - mason jars for the drinks, cool lighting fixtures, and a general ambiance of a hip bar. The food does not disappoint - the saag paneer (a classic) was done just right, and my malai kofta was delicious. I was so full by the end that I couldn't even fit in any rice pudding, but that probably had something to do with their tasty and different rose lassi, which I highly recommend. It did take a long time for a waiter to come around for the check at the end, but the service was generally good and friendly. Dhaba is on a street filled with Indian restaurants (I counted six others within one block), but I'd recommend this over most of them.
reviewTitle: Great Indian food at a reasonable price

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Tried this place as it was recommended, clearly by someone who was not a fan of Indian food or good service.
The food was mediocre, at best. I asked for white meat but was served Indeterminable grey meat that looked like it had been chewed up and spat out. I like a vindaloo but for some reason it has excessive amounts of vinegar in the US so I asked for it without vinegar. They ignored that and it was almost overbearing.
I was dressed in  a shift dress and flats as had just finished work and I ate an early dinner, I just wanted something tasty to eat. Because I wasn't dressed up they behaved in an appallingly pretentious manner as if I should have overdressed to be served substandard food. I won't be returning.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
They had 9 selections on the table including a shrimp dish. They bring out fresh Naan bread after you sit down. They also serve Tandoori directly from the kitchen so the chicken is moist rather than being dried out on the buffet table.

I tried 6 of the dishes. All quite tasty.

However, they only have rice pudding for dessert. Some better restaurants have 2-3 choices for dessert.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Delicious, authentic northern Indian cuisine at a good price. How can you not like this place? Originally introduced to it by an Indian friend, who vouches for its authenticity, we now go back regularly. The only criticism I would make, and it's a small one, it that it can become quite crowded and noisy.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Nott recommend anbody to go there as food was not as per the standard and it was cold and customer service was bad more over bit expensive

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Loved the chicken tikka masala, garlic nan. My friend had the lamb korma and a rose lassi. Enjoyed my mango lassi. Highly recommend.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We saw this place and picked it for dinner as we wanted Indian and it was getting more traffic than any other (similar) place around.  The place was full with mostly young people.  The atmosphere is lively, service was very good and we really enjoyed the food.  I would try to avoid a table in the middle of the dining room to avoid being in the hustle bustle.  We would go back.
reviewTitle: Busy, busy place with very nice food

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Another great meal here! On 07/17/2012, our group of five dined here. one of us has a peanut allergy, so from past experience we know that they will be able to deal with that issue. Sure, there are higher priced Indian Restaurants, BUT the food is the same! So, here we are again!

The garlic Naan is wonderful and cooked just right. We ordered two servings of white meat chicken tika marsala. The two orders of Basmati Rice were very enjoyable as was the mango chutney. So many items were ordered that I just cna't recall all of their names. However, I remember that every ordered item was excellent

As to some of the lower ratings for this or any buffet serving restaurant: We have dined here several times--always avoiding the Buffet as it's too mild and lacking in flavor. The problem with any buffet is--it's prepared mild for most people and kept warm. We always order our meals with medium spice level which really isn't that spicey. If this is your first time, just order mild.

We will return for another great meal here during the coming months. The draft Indian Beer is wonderful served in a cold glass---refreshing during a hot day!
reviewTitle: One Of The Best Indian Restaurants Around

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Recommended by a friend, this place offer excellent value.  We ate there for lunch and found the food to be very good.   There were 2 choices of ordering - a la carte or buffet style menu.  The buffet at $12/head is hard to beat with at least 8 menu choices including a number of vegetarian options.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The S. Indian fare is authentic and delicious here, even the lassi (mango) stands for itself. Miles ahead of Junoon in sincerity and honest, simple Indian cuisine. Don't expect any floral or frilly atmosphere!
reviewTitle: Solid food amid tired Bollywood background.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Small and a bit noisy restaurant but it was not a problem because the food was excellent!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Place was quite small but we managed to have table for two in saturday night without reservation. Food was excellent and very authentic.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I've been to India many times and eat the food often in the states.  We sampled a variety of dishes, including Raita, Papad, Chicken Butter Masala, Dal Tadka, and Chicken Dahiwala.  Everything tasted fresh and well seasoned, and the ingredients seemed top notch.  Our waiter was attentive and the staff was on the spot with water refills, plate clearing etc.   I'd definitely go back.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We went there based on the many positive reviews. But, sadly, the food is simply not very good. Very bland. Lacking in spice. As authentic as you could get from a Trader Joe's frozen Indian dish. I used to live in India so I have a decent read on quality. This isn't it. Very disappointing.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We've dined at DhaBa several times. To those who rated Restaurants based upon the BUFFET, get real. Buffets tend to be bland to appeal to the masses–nothing more or less. It is mild/bland food placed out upon warmers.  We avoid buffets wherever and whenever. For us, the Buffet offers no real value except the "all you can eat" syndrome. The ordered portion size is more than enough. We demand that our food be cooked to order and served hot temperature wise–nothing more or less. For our dinner at DhaBa we ordered garlic naan along with chicken tikka masala and tandori chicken + rice. We did order an appetizer that had chick peas, sorry but I do not recall the name–it was so good that we ordered another! I usually order Indian food medium spice wise. This visit,  my Son & his Girlfriend joined me--- it was their first Indian experience, so I ordered everything mild. Also she had a nut allergy, so I asked if they could accommodate her restriction. The waiter checked and reported back that they could avoid nuts and their byproducts. We had a great dinner and she had no after effects. They will return on their own in the near future. For me, upon my next NYC visit, I'll be back!
reviewTitle: An Excellent Meal At A Reasonable Price.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: The food here is good.  It isn't like anything I've ever eaten in India -- more of a fusion, but good non-the-less.  The staff is less good.  I left my iphone on the table and called as soon as I realized it.  I could not get a civil response and was told to call back the next day.  It was undoubtedly taken by a staff person -- busperson or someone.  The table next to us was not occupied.  We called the next day and were told in a barely civil way to call at noon.  We won't return.  These things happen, but the refusal to even check it out was not forgivable.  If this hadn't happened I'd say we got a reasonable meal for a pretty high price.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Whenever we visit NY, we tend to trek down to the Dhaba on Lexington Avenue. The lunchtime buffet there is better than the curry fare one is likely to find in the other Indian non-veg restaurants in the vicinity. Even so, the buffet, on the day we lunched here,  was just OK. For some reason, all the curries tasted the same even though they had different names. Among the stand-out items were the garlic naans and the piece of tandoori chicken which is served. Nothing that would make one want to go to this place again except if one is really hungry or one is in the mood for some curry. Two other let downs: The really dark interior and the very loud music. When requested to turn the music a wee bit down, the chief 'waitress' told us quite sharply that restaurants always have loud music. (I took the tone of her voice to mean: Get used to it, finish your buffet and get lost).  And then, she mercifully turned down the volume of that quite sharp music.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Wonderful place to eat, enjoy indian music and a perfect atmosphere.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
This restaurant is extremely popular so if your heart is set on eating here a reservation is required. Otherwise you will have to wait for an indeterminate time for your table. The tables are cramped together and we have experienced all varieties of service here from great to awful. 
However, this restaurant is a good option for vegans dining with carnivores, they have excellent vegan options especially the Aloo Jeera. I have always been very happy with the food here its good, fresh and tasty, but the service is hit/miss.
reviewTitle: Great Food, mixed service, reservations required

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: A terrific new place in Curry Hill. We had a vegan appetizer of cauliflower and peas with many spices, a chicken tandoori that was ambrosial, and an excellent lamb jalfrazie. We also had a couple orders of the excellent masala tea- a spiced Indian beverage with milk,and finished up with soupy but very tasty rice pudding. Have the onion- chili naan; it is described as hot but is merely spicy and very tasty. A great meal, but service is odd.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
I dug around on the Chowhound boards for some discussion about Indian restaurants in Curry Hill.  Two I was interested in were South Indian and one of our party was looking for meat, so Dhaba was our choice.  This was a pretty traditional Northern Indian (will go for the South Indian veg meals on our next trip!) with the addition of some fun chaats for starters.  I love Bhel Poori and this one did not disappoint.  My husband and I gobbled it down happily.  One of the best I have had lately.  We  also ordered a lamb keema which was nicely hot.  The Chicken Tikka Masala was kind of bland, but basically made my kid happy.  

When we first sat down, the music was bad Indian rock (or something!) and very loud.  After a while, they switched to a more easy-to-listen-to Bollywood style music.  The service was friendly but the place really packed up after we'd been there a while and it felt like it was starting to get stressful.  Tables are super close together and if we'd not been in a booth, I might have felt a bit like I was sitting in my neighbor's lap!  I had to do a little dance to exit the booth at the end of the meal.  Eeek!

As I said in my title, it would be best to arrive a little early.  We did so just around 6pm.  Generally, we find that eating a big, late breakfast and an early dinner makes for the least crowded dining situations in NYC.  We save a little money and have room for some street snacks by not eating three meals a day.  When we left the restaurant, there was a clutch of would-be diners waiting for tables.  Every other restaurant on the block ( and there are a ton of Indian restos here!) was practically deserted.  Good sign!

We had dinner for three, two beers and the bill came to $65....almost unheard of in NYC!
reviewTitle: Key to Success - get here early!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: un locale piacevolmente colorato nel cuore del quartiere indiano su Lexington Ave e 27th street, ma affollato e rumoroso. Difficile chiacchierare con toni normali e difficile anche leggere il menu che e' ricchissimo, ma scritto in caratteri talmente piccoli da rimanere misterioso nella luce volutamente bassissima dell'ambiente. Il cibo e' buono, anche se a volte troppo piccante, i camerieri gentili, ma lo spazio e' stretto e alla fine l'esperienza complessiva non e' da ripetere. A meno di andarci per pranzo, con la luce del giorno e il locale non pieno. Forse allora l'attenzione potra' essere solo sui piatti.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I went with friends and had the Pav bhaji and it was a bit greasy, the ambience is nice, and the service is good. I went again and ordered rotis and indian vegetarian dishes and again the vegetarian dishes were floating in oil.
reviewTitle: Good Food, North Indian, a little greasy.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
This was my third trip to Dhaba.  I think the food is great.  We had a reservation and due to the weather arrived about five minutes late.  It was cold, windy and rainy that night.  A gentleman greeted us and told us he would be right with us.  He then went toward the back to set some tables.  A woman walked up and then pointed us to a table that was two feet from the front door.  I told her no, we didn't want to sit right at the front door and that the gentleman was taking care of us.  He never came back.  So I found him and he said we had to ask the hostess for our table.  She then started giving me attitude that I had declined the table she offered...
It all worked out.  We sat in a booth and had a great dinner, despite the fact that they were out of paneer.  Seriously??
It's a lively crowd, great food, a bit noisy.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We had booked a table for three for 730pm and arrived right on on time. Chaos reigned it seemed . No table  and no real idea what seemed to be going on. by the staff-or manager for that matter. Eventually seated at 8 pm and things settled down  (watching other pre bookers left to wait). However by then whole experience spoilt by the wait. Food OK but   I live in London and used to far better there though there were plenty of Indian customers in which is a good sign. Would prob advise take out service rather than inhouse-and still be prepared to wait..........

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Dhaba suffers from the curse of the popular restaurant -- too many diners want to eat there, and not enough capacity to seat them.  We hit it on a Friday night with a reservation and there was a queue out the door.  Worse was that the front of house were incapable of giving realistic estimates to the people in the line re how long theyd have to wait.  One group were promised a 10 minute wait and were still standing around an hour later.  The net effect was that the lobby was full of angry potential diners and the staff were rushing the folks at their tables through their meals.  So all in all, good food spoilt by bad management.  if you want to go, book a table.
reviewTitle: Good food, bad front of house

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This place is yummy and cheap. Great lunch spot. It is kinda small but the service is quick.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I ordered my food for delivery at 5:04 and it finally arrived now at 6:38pm! I called and checked on my food delivery 6 times and the manager on duty Raj would not say anything but, "the delivery guy has left the building". Sadly, this is my 4th Sunday where dhaba has made me wait OVER AN HOUR for a seamless web email confirmation of 25-40 minutes! Forget customer service, they can't even guarantee that you will get your food- isn't that the whole point of Seamless web?! Absolutely pathetic, don't bother ordering from here, you will wait too long and be too angry at them to even enjoy the food (if it comes).
reviewTitle: DON'T BOTHER ORDERING FROM HERE, YOU WILL WAIT TOO LONG AND BE TOO ANGRY AT THEM TO EVEN ENJOY THE FOOD.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: During a week in NYC we went here twice! Amazing food, nice servers, basically amazing! But on our last day a guy who sat besides waited for his food for a loooooong time, he was upset and asked what's where going on?? The server did know what to do, and instead of checking just ignored the guy.. The made a scene lateron. Nevertheless we were very satisfied:)
reviewTitle: Very good! But everyone makes mistakes...

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I would recommend this restaurant to travellers who are keen on having good food. I have now been there many times and have not been disappointed. Do try the "Purani Delhi Ki Papri Chaat".  Also I would recommend the "Chicken Kali Mirch". It is not a place where you would go for a romantic or business meal.  Enjoy.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Kleines Restaurant mit eng zusammengestellten Tischen (Ausnahme vielleicht die Anhöhe am Fenster, wo wir saßen).
Eine gute Karte mit einer sehr guten Auswahl an Currys (außerhalb Deutschlands ist scharf übrigens in der Regel auch wirklich scharf und nicht nur würzig!).
Dazu eine gute Auswahl an Lassis und Bieren (Weizenbier vom Fass, Radeberger, Gaffel Kölsch und andere aus der Flasche für 5,-$/Flasche).

Alles recht preiswert gerade im Vergleich zu anderen New Yorker Restaurants. 
Es war sehr lecker und die Portionen waren reichlich. Wir haben nicht alles geschafft und den Rest unaufgefordert in Warmhalteboxen mitbekommen.

Reservierung ist definitiv wichtig. Wir hatten online reserviert und in der ganzen Zeit von 19°°-21°°Uhr war nicht ein einziger Platz frei! Die Gäste standen Schlange bis auf die Straße. Zugegeben, es war Freitag, aber sicher ist sicher!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Not heavy like the other indian joints. Felt like home cooked food.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: 'Goan fish' is my favorite but my kids like Chicken Makkhani'. Make reservations or be prepared to wait. I only wish there was a place to wait other then outside the restaurant like a bar..

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This restaurant was absolutely awesome! I have never been to an Indian restaurant where the food, the ambiance, and the service were spectacular! I ordered the Chicken Curry, which is definitely something to try; it is very good. My two sons ordered a Mango Lassi and also enjoyed that very much, too. I recommend this to anyone who wishes to eat here! It is a great places for couples and families alike!
reviewTitle: One of the best Indian restaurants I've ever been to!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: We went for lunch and the service was great.  The food was excellent and we weren't disappointed.  Loved the Indian techno music, unique decor, great choices on the buffet, an appetizer was included and they even brought just cooked dishes to our table!!!  We'll be back next time we're in New York.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: This place was crowded, lively, and fun on a Friday night. We had to wait  a little for our table despite having a reservation, but the restaurant hosts couldn't have been more apologetic and nice about it. The service was attentive but not hovering, and our server was engaged, interested, and happy to give recommendations based on our tastes. The food itself was very good -- not big portions, but Indian restaurants usually seem to have small portions. The champagne lassi was a nice twist on an old favorite, and even the goat -- our most challenging dish -- tasted great (though I could have used a warning about the bones). A big menu of solid Indian favorites -- nothing spectacular, but consistently good food.
reviewTitle: LIvely atmosphere, good food and service

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: My husband and I went to New York in May 2010- after a few days of eating fried food we were longing for some spcey curry. I knew there was an area in New York City - Curry hll, so we  headed there - disappointingly there were only a few resturants to chose from- beware, the indian cuisine resturants in the area mostly do not serve alcohol -  being British Asians by husband I needed a pint of Tiger with our curry - we found the Dhaba on Lexington av - the place was packed with locals both white and asian which was a good sign. We had to wait 15 minutes for a table but the wait was well worth it. The resturant is small, so the food it cooked fresh and is piping hot. Being of an Asian back ground, you can rely on my view that the food was wonderful! very tasty, service was great and as we went after the rush on week night we got a nice romantic booth to ourselves. So if you're in new york and need something with a bit of taste to awaken the taste buds again, then this is the place!!

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: I have gone to many Indian restaurants in my life in various Western cities but have not found such authentic food at such reasonable prices.  You must try the Purani Dili Papri Chaat - it is truly authentic - as it should be - crispy, not too much tamarind or yoghurt and with just the right amount of spices.  It is very busy - so you must book.
reviewTitle: The best for good food at reasonable price

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText:
Nice looking from the outside.
Pretty disinterested wait staff.
Samosas, chaat and goan fish curry just didn't taste all that good.
I love Indian food and I might give this place a second try but was
disappointed this time.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: My new favorite indian restaurant because of its comprehensive menu from street food to more elaborate dishes. And it all tastes good. We tried the bhel puri, butter chicken, goat biryani, baigan da bharta and roomali roti. Must go back for the paya and the makki di roti/sarson ka saag soon. The preparation is very Punjabi/Delhite and a bit spicy. Which is excactly what I was looking for.
reviewTitle: My new favorite indian restaurant because of its comprehensive menu from street food to more elaborate dishes. And it...

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: Knowing "true" Indian cuisine - altogether I have spent 5 months in India - I find this restaurant very genuine. The price is a plus - if you have the buffet and drink a bear you are at about 20$.

placeAddress: 108 Lexington Ave, New York City, NY 10016-8927
reviewText: They are a bit expensive, the food is good but not the best. The decor is somewhat nice, especially inside the restrooms!
reviewTitle: They are a bit expensive, the food is good but not the best. The decor is somewhat nice, especially inside the...

placeName: West Bar and Lounge - St. Albans
reviewText: Absolutely freaking delicious. Ordered the Rib Eye Steak and Rum Bar Wings. The Wings were very flavorful, perfectly prepared, the glaze has nice flavor. The Rib Eye was cooked perfectly, was tender, nice portion. Mashed potatoes also flavorful, not bland and nice and fluffy, and the asparagus was also perfectly prepared, had  little crunch, weren't soggy and nicely seasoned. This was my first time ordering from this restaurant, guarantee I will be patronizing them again...........Soon.
